abstract.text: A mutable nonowning collection interface to the bytes in a
region of memory.

inlineContent.text: You can use an
instance in low-level operations to eliminate
uniqueness checks and release mode bounds checks. Bounds checks are always
performed in debug mode.
An
instance is a view of the raw bytes in a region of memory.
Each byte in memory is viewed as a
value independent of the type
of values held in that memory. Reading from and writing to memory through
a raw buffer are untyped operations. Accessing this collectionâ€™s bytes
does not bind the underlying memory to
In addition to its collection interface, an
instance also supports the following methods provided by
, including bounds checks in debug mode:
To access the underlying memory through typed operations, the memory must
be bound to a trivial type.
A
trivial type
can be copied bit for bit with no indirection
or reference-counting operations. Generally, native Swift types that do
not contain strong or weak references or other forms of indirection are
trivial, as are imported C structs and enums. Copying memory that
contains values of nontrivial types can only be done safely with a typed
pointer. Copying bytes directly from nontrivial, in-memory values does
not produce valid copies and can only be done by calling a C API, such as
An
instance is a view into memory and does not own the memory
that it references. Copying a variable or constant of type
does
not copy the underlying memory. However, initializing another collection
with an
instance copies bytes out of the referenced memory and
into the new collection.
The following example uses
, an
instance, to
demonstrate the difference between assigning a buffer pointer and using a
buffer pointer as the source for another collectionâ€™s elements. Here, the
assignment to
creates a new, nonowning buffer pointer
covering the first
bytes of the memory that
referencesâ€”nothing is copied:
Next, the bytes referenced by
are copied into
, a
new
array, and then the remainder of
is appended to
Assigning into a ranged subscript of an
instance copies bytes
into the memory. The next
bytes of the memory that
references are copied in this code:

abstract.text: A mutable nonowning collection interface to the bytes in a
region of memory.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
Initializes the memory referenced by this buffer with the given value,
binds the memory to the valueâ€™s type, and returns a typed buffer of the
initialized memory.
Moves every element of an initialized source buffer into the
uninitialized memory referenced by this buffer, leaving the source memory
uninitialized and this bufferâ€™s memory initialized.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging
purposes.
Copies the bytes from the given buffer to this bufferâ€™s memory.
Executes the given closure while temporarily binding the buffer to
instances of type
A sequence whose elements can be traversed multiple times,
nondestructively, and accessed by an indexed subscript.
Moves every element of an initialized source buffer slice into the
uninitialized memory referenced by this buffer, leaving the source memory
uninitialized and this bufferâ€™s memory initialized.
Stores a valueâ€™s bytes into the buffer pointerâ€™s raw memory at the
specified byte offset.
Binds this bufferâ€™s memory to the specified type and returns a typed
buffer of the bound memory.
Initializes the bufferâ€™s memory with the given elements, binding the
initialized memory to the elementsâ€™ type.
A collection that supports efficient random-access index traversal.
Returns a new instance of the given type, read from the buffer pointerâ€™s
raw memory at the specified byte offset.
Copies from a collection of
into this bufferâ€™s memory.
A collection that supports subscript assignment.
A collection that supports backward as well as forward traversal.
Returns a new instance of the given type, constructed from the raw memory
at the specified offset.
A type that provides sequential, iterated access to its elements.
Creates a raw buffer over the contiguous bytes in the given typed buffer.
Creates a raw buffer over the same memory as the given raw buffer slice,
with the indices rebased to zero.
Creates a new mutable buffer over the same memory as the given buffer.
Creates a new buffer over the same memory as the given buffer.
Initializes the bufferâ€™s memory with every element of the source,
binding the initialized memory to the elementsâ€™ type.
